newsitem.title: CANADA: Tee-Comm shares fall, future in doubt.
newsitem.headline: Tee-Comm shares fall, future in doubt.

text.p: Heavy selling wiped out half the value of Tee-Comm Electronics Inc shares on Thursday after the satellite television provider's future was cast into doubt.
Tee-Comm, which took on the big direct broadcast satellite players in the United States with its own offering and recently launched a service in Canada, suffered a liquidity crunch this week.
The company said on Thursday and may propose to its convertible subordinated debentureholders a swap of debentures for equity and the investment of additional capital.
The stock collapsed 1.05, or 51.22 percent, to 1.00 in turnover of 2.62 million shares.

"(Tee-Comm is) going to have a very, very difficult time going forward because even if the debenture-holders did agree to convert into common equity, it still doesn't change the fact that they are draining C$5 or C$6 million per month. Somebody has to fund that," said Doug Cunningham, a cable television industry analyst at Midland Walwyn Capital Inc.
"They need a new source of financing, over and above any re-negotiation with the debenture holders because they are in a liquidity crisis," he added.

Cunningham said Tee-Comm set itself up for a fall when it took on deep-pocketed giants like News Corp, MCI Communications Corp and Hughes (Electronics Corp) Direct with its AlphaStar satellite offering in the United States.

"When some of the U.S. players are prepared to subsidize the satellite receiving equipment up front, it's a very, very expensive proposition and unfortunately Tee-Comm did not have the financial circumstance to participate in that," he said.
Tee-Comm's problems were compounded when they were late getting into the U.S. market.
Company officials were not available for comment.
Cunningham said Tee-Comm is unlikely to prove an attractive merger prospect for either a U.S. or Canadian direct-to-home satellite player.
"I don't believe that Tee-Comm is necessarily large enough from a subscriber point of view to be of interest to any of the other U.S. competitors," Cunningham said.
Tee-Comm has about 43,000 subscribers in the United States and roughly 5,000 in Canada.
Although the financial problems at Tee-Comm did not come as a surprise to the market, much of the stock is in the hands of retail investors who had hoped the dark clouds would pass.
Traders said this is why the stock tumbled so sharply despite the suspicions of investors.

One analyst, who declined to be identified, said he thought debtholders may let the company go forward with its business plan after weighing the value of Tee-Comm's assets with the potential the company could bail itself out.
"It's arguably worth more if they let it follow its business plan for some time," the analyst said.

"But from a business point of view, if this company were liquidated, what would its assets be. Boxes of no value, there would also be the uplink centers and the AT&T (satellite space) lease," he added.
Cunningham said the company may be forced to seek court protection if its debtholders fail to okay its proposal.
"That may happen in the near-term, it really depends on the debenture holders in the short-term," he said.
"I do not believe that the debenture holders are going to wait any longer."
